III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth J was hit by a car while trying to AWOL during an outing.
Investigation Documents reviewed:
MISACWIS indicates Youth J, was placed in Wolverine Center’s
Emergency Shelter on 1/20/24 and still had not been permanently
placed as of 2/27/24. Wolverine Shelter is his first out of home
placement.
I visually observed Youth J’s psychotropic medications. He
currently is prescribed Depakote, Abilify, Trazodone, Xanex and a
form of Adderall.
Hospital emergency room discharge instructions dated 2/28/24
diagnosed Youth J with Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder.
Hospital emergency room discharge instructions dated 2/28/24
diagnosed Youth N with Adjustment Disorder.
An incident report by Staff 1 dated 2/27/24 at 6:45pm was
consistent with the information she reported when interviewed.
Interviews:
I notified Youth J’s Foster Care Worker of this investigation
assignment, and she expressed no licensing concerns regarding
Wolverine Center.
I contacted Complainant/Youth J’s Grandmother. She said Youth
J’s mother called her hollering and screaming worried about Youth
J. “He’s incompetent and they won’t tell nobody where he is at.” I
encouraged Complainant to contact Youth J’s foster care worker
2

for more information. Complainant agreed to contact the foster
care worker and expressed no additional licensing concerns
regarding Wolverine Center.
I notified Chief Administrator (CA) via phone of the allegations.
She was aware of the incident but was not aware an investigation
was initiated. CA reported Youth J was not hit by a car but said
he did run into the road. CA said Youth J was not physically
injured but was taken to the hospital for a psychiatric crisis
assessment afterward.
I interviewed Youth J, onsite on 3/1/24. He presented with a dull
affect, had difficulty remembering his birthdate, and appeared
much younger than his age. Wolverine Center is his first
placement outside of his parents’ home. Youth J said he has
“outbursts” during which he throws chairs and has been
hospitalized twice for suicidal ideations. I asked Youth J if he
broke a van window. He nodded and said he did it because he
was leaving the park and did not want to leave. He wanted to go
home (to his parents). I asked if he was hit by a car and Youth J
shook his head “no.” However, he did admit he intentionally ran in
front of a car “because I wanted to end myself.” I asked why he
wanted to end himself, Youth J shrugged, “just upset.” Afterward
he said he was seen at a hospital. The hospital staff asked him
questions and sent him back to the facility.
I interviewed Youth N, at school on 3/5/24. His affect was dull,
speech was slow, and he was unable to provide details of events
in chronological sequence. Youth N said he has been at
Wolverine Center for three months and did not want to talk about
anything. I asked what happened on the outing to the park, he
was more amenable to talking about Youth J’s behaviors than his
own. Youth N said Youth J ran away from staff first. “I ran away
too. We were hiding from the cops scared we’d go to jail. A
family said they’d give us money. I scratched paint off a truck.
Youth J tried jumping out the window. I tried to choke myself. We
ran toward cars. The cops got us. We went to the hospital.”
Youth N was unwilling or unable to say what caused his behaviors
and refused to provide any additional information.
I interviewed Youth R at school on 3/20/24. He said Youth J did
not want to leave the park, so he and Youth N ran from staff and
into the street. The police came. Inside the van, Youth J broke a
window out and Youth N tried breaking the van door. Youth N
choked himself with a seatbelt. “I punched one woman staff in the
3

chest because Youth J made me mad…The cops came and put
Youth J in back of the cop car.”
I interviewed Former Youth D at school on 3/20/24. He was
discharged from the facility on 3/5/24. Former Youth D presented
with a dull affect and had difficulty focusing on the questions that
were asked. He said he recalled Youth J and Youth N ran in the
street at the park and the “staff tried to get them out.” He said the
boys were not hurt. I asked about the staff at Wolverine Center,
Former Youth D nodded “good.” He was unable to remember any
additional details regarding the incident at the park.
I interviewed Staff 1 onsite on 3/5/24. She has only worked at the
facility for one month. Staff 1 said she and Staff 2 took four short-
term shelter youths to Belle Isle. There is a one-way road around
its perimeter. Staff 1 stated the youths played football, made new
friends, and had fun until it was time to leave the park. Three
boys were in the van, but Youth J would not get in because he
wanted to talk to a girl. Youth J ran away from the van, and
everyone followed him. From a distance he was seen banging on
gas pipelines and walking into oncoming traffic. Staff 2 ran into
the street after Youth J. Then Youth N also walked into oncoming
traffic. Neither boy was hit by a car or injured in any way.
After walking toward cars, Youth J and Youth N ran into a field.
Staff 2 called the police who located the youths and brought them
back to the van. In the presence of police, a stranger gave each
of the boys a five- or twenty-dollar bill. Youth N got angry and told
the stranger he wanted more money. Staff 3 arrived at the park to
assist and drove everyone back to the facility, leaving the van they
came in at the park. On the ride back, Staff 1 said Youth J kicked
out a van window because he did not want to leave the park.
Youth N wrapped a seatbelt around his neck because the stranger
only gave him twenty dollars. He bit Staff 2’s hand when she tried
to remove the seatbelt from his hands. Staff 3 stopped the van
and called the police again. Youth N and Youth J exited the van
and walked into traffic again on East Jefferson. Police arrived
again and secured the boys. Staff told the police they did not feel
safe driving with Youth N and Youth J. Upon return to the facility
both youths were transported to the hospital for psychiatric
evaluations and released back to Wolverine Center.
I interviewed Former Staff 2 via phone on 3/20/24. She no longer
works at the facility and feels she was unjustly terminated for an
unrelated matter. Former Staff 2 said she was traumatized by the
4

youths’ behaviors on the outing and was never thanked by
administrators for saving the youths’ lives.
Regarding the incident at the park, Youth J was upset because he
wanted to stay at the park. He and Youth N ran into the street and
would not follow staff directives. “I kept line of sight and called the
police. The police found the boys, and both were irate. Youth N
choked himself with a seatbelt while Youth J kicked out a window.
I held onto Youth J so he did not fall out while keeping Youth N
from choking himself. Staff 3 stopped the van. The boys got out
and ran into East Jefferson. I was able to grab both of them.
Youth J and Youth N both said they wanted to die. The police had
followed us home from the park and brought both youths back to
the facility in their police car.”
I interviewed Staff 3 via phone on 3/20/24. She was at the facility
and volunteered to drive to Belle Isle to assist Staff 1 and Staff 2.
Before locating her coworkers, she saw a police car and Youth J
and Youth N running away from police. When the youths were
secured, Staff 3 drove everyone in one van back to the facility.
On the way back, Youth J broke a window and Staff 2 held him in
with his behind sticking out the window. “I pulled over as soon as
possible. It was dark. Youth J and N hopped out and walked into
traffic. Staff 2 retrieved Youth J and I called the police.” The
police arrived and drove both youths back in the police car.
Analysis Youth J and Youth N intentionally ran into oncoming traffic twice
during an outing on 2/27/24. Staff 1 and Staff 2 intervened and
neither of the boys were injured or hit by a car. The two boys ran
from staff, the police were called, found them and brought them to
staff. Staff 2 removed a seatbelt Youth N wrapped around his
neck. Staff 3 stopped the van for safety and both boys ran into
the road again. Police were called again and brought the boys
back to the van. Upon return to the facility, both boys were taken
to the emergency room for a psychiatric assessment.
CONSULTATION
To maintain safety of youth in the short-term program, I
recommended all short-term shelter youths only attend
recreational activities on-grounds and not be eligible for off-
grounds activities.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It was alleged Youth J was "tortured" at the facility.
Investigation I asked Youth J to tell me about him and other youths being
“tortured” at the facility. He responded, “They’re not…I just said
that in case I’d go home.”
Youth N also denied that he or anyone else was tortured at the
facility.
Youth R said “Youth J and Youth N lied” that staff abused them.
“It is not true.”
Youth D said staff at the facility are “good” and do not hurt youths.
Analysis There is no evidence youths are physically punished or tortured at
the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
